item.title: Where to Watch Catherine O’Hara’s Best Performances, From ‘Beetlejuice’ to ‘Best in Show’
item.description: Her characters were as varied as they were eccentric and lovable. These are some of the best.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara won a best lead actress Emmy for her role as the down-and-out former millionaire Moira Rose in the sitcom “Schitt’s Creek.”

item.title: Catherine O’Hara: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The Canadian actress’s career spanned decades and genres, including memorable roles in “Home Alone” and “Schitt’s Creek.”
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara photographed in 1986 in Los Angeles.

item.title: They’re Stepping Up on ‘The Pitt’
item.description: Four actors discuss the evolution of their young clinician characters on “The Pitt.” In Season 2 they are a little older, a little wiser and still soaked in fake blood.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Sela Shiloni

item.title: Yahya Abdul-Mateen II Starts His Days With This Podcast
item.description: “It’s basically professional barbershop talk with an unfiltered delivery,” said the star of the new Marvel series “Wonder Man.”
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck

item.title: On ‘Shrinking,’ Jessica Williams Moves the Needle
item.description: The actor has received Emmy nominations for both seasons of “Shrinking” and knows she’s capable of even more. She just needs the chance to prove it.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2 Episode 4 Recap: Wanna Bet?
item.description: A nearby hospital closes its doors temporarily, sending extra patients and chaos to the Pitt. Time for another office pool.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Dr. McKay (Fiona Dourif) took a gamble all her own by asking out a patient.

item.title: ‘Wonder Man’ Pushes Marvel Into Unfamiliar Territory
item.description: The studio’s latest series for Disney+ stars Yahya Abdul-Mateen II as a struggling actor whose superpowers are a problem.
item.dc:creator: Adam B. Vary

item.title: ‘Wonder Man’ Review: A Break From the Multiverse
item.description: In Marvel’s latest series on Disney+, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II and Ben Kingsley star as struggling actors who would rather play heroes than be heroes.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale

item.title: In ‘Memory of a Killer,’ Patrick Dempsey Takes the Wheel
item.description: The actor has spent a decade dismantling his McDreamy persona from “Grey’s Anatomy.” He stars as an assassin in a new Fox thriller.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Nathan Cyprys
item.media:credit: Nathan Cyprys for The New York Times

item.title: Demond Wilson, Long-Suffering Son on ‘Sanford and Son,’ Dies at 79
item.description: As Lamont, he was a young man in constant battle with his father and business partner, played by Redd Foxx, on the popular 1970s series.
item.dc:creator: Anita Gates
item.media:credit: NBCU Photo Bank, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Wilson, left, in 1972 on “Sanford and Son” with Redd Foxx, who played his character’s father.

item.title: Mark Carney Meets ‘Heated Rivalry’ Star Hudson Williams
item.description: Only one thing could make the TV show and cultural phenomenon “Heated Rivalry” more Canadian: pairing one of its stars, Hudson Williams, with Prime Minister Mark Carney in the nation’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney and Hudson Williams of “Heated Rivalry” on the red carpet in Ottawa.

item.title: ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ Fans Flock to Korean Language Classes
item.description: Across the country, Americans who love K-pop and K-dramas are flocking to Korean language classes.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times

item.title: How Lesley Manville Is Leaving ‘Oedipus’ Audiences Spellbound
item.description: Personal history emerges by painful degrees in “Oedipus,” whose language and story, the actress Lesley Manville says, “wreck me every time.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Brantley
item.media:description: Lesley Manville portrays Jocasta in Robert Icke’s retelling of the Greek tragedy.

item.title: Macaulay Culkin And Others Pay Tribute to Catherine O’Hara After Her Death
item.description: Videos and photos filled social media as fans shared their favorite scenes from O’Hara’s acting career and co-stars memorialized her.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in 2019. The actress died this week at the age of 71.

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, ‘Home Alone’ and ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Actress, Dies at 71
item.description: An Emmy-winning comedian with oddball charm, she got her start with the influential Canadian sketch comedy series “SCTV.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams and Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

item.title: Peyton List Steps Into ‘Heathers’ for Her Off Broadway Debut
item.description: She watched the movie as a teenager, now the star of “School Spirits” and “Cobra Kai” is playing the acid-tongued queen bee Heather Chandler onstage.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peyton List taking her bow in “Heathers: The Musical” at New World Stages on Monday.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Teases ‘Melania’
item.description: The late night host said, “Not since ‘The Terminator’ has there been this much excitement for a movie about a European cyborg.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Late Night Praises Ilhan Omar’s Quick Reflexes
item.description: Stephen Colbert said the Minneapolis congresswoman looked “ready to throw some hands” after a man sprayed a substance at her at a town hall.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Geoff Mason, Sports Producer Thrust Into Covering Terrorism, Dies at 85
item.description: He played a critical role in ABC Sports’s reporting on the attack by a Palestinian group at the 1972 Summer Games in Munich that left 11 Israeli team members dead.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: American Broadcasting Companies, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Geoffrey Mason, with ABC Sports, at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Alberta, Canada. He won 24 Emmy Awards for producing coverage of sports events.

item.title: When Bruce Springsteen (Hank Azaria) Met Michael Stipe (Michael Shannon)
item.description: Both actors pay homage to rock ’n’ roll greats onstage. But their relationships to their muses — and how they perform their songs — are very different.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times

item.title: Nuclear Anxiety, That Staple of 1980s Cinema, Is Back
item.description: After the Cold War ended, our terror of nuclear war faded from the screen. Now it’s resurgent — and more fatalistic than ever.
item.dc:creator: Trevor Quirk

item.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Sondheim
item.description: Judy Collins, Mandy Patinkin, Renée Fleming, Michael R. Jackson, Melissa Errico, Tony Kushner, Sherman Irby and New York Times writers and editors pick 14 songs to seal the deal.
item.category: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (Play)
A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum (Play)
Sunday in the Park with George (Play)
I Wish I Could Forget You (Song)

item.title: Desi Lydic Says Gregory Bovino Got ‘Iced Out’
item.description: “We’re not throwing you under the bus — we’re throwing you onto a bus, and sending it far, far away,” the “Daily Show” host said of the recalled Border Patrol official.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Volcano,’ the L.A. Disaster Movie That Boils Over With Unintended Comedy
item.description: Tommy Lee Jones and Anne Heche teamed up in their heyday to save Los Angeles from lava in this big-budget 1997 film that defies all logic to fantastic, farcical effect.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: Seth Meyers Won’t Let ICE Co-Opt the Weather
item.description: “Just think about it, ICE is so unpopular, they want FEMA to not use the word ‘ice,’” the late night host said of the immigration enforcement agency.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Bridgerton,’ Plus 5 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: This Regency-era drama is back for a fourth season, and the 2026 Grammy Awards will air.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Luke Thompson and Yerin Ha in “Bridgerton.”

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1 Episode 2 Recap: A Man Among Princes
item.description: A certain royal family known for dragons and blond hair arrives on the scene. One of our heroes, at least, seems appropriately wary.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)
item.media:description: Dunk and Egg (Peter Claffey, left, and Dexter Sol Ansell) have notably different reactions when the Targaryens ride onto the scene.

item.title: Floyd Vivino, Throwback Comedian Known as Uncle Floyd, Dies at 74
item.description: His silly, vaudeville-style variety show was filled with his piano playing, skits, puppets and guest stars like Cyndi Lauper and Jon Bon Jovi.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Mr. Vivino in 1984. He was sometimes compared to Soupy Sales, a slapstick comic who hosted a syndicated children’s program. Uncle Floyd’s silly absurdism also seemed to augur the arrival of Pee-wee Herman.

item.title: Geese Gives ‘Saturday Night Live’ Viewers Something to Talk About
item.description: The buzzy Brooklyn band brought its off-kilter aesthetic to network TV this weekend, with performances that were both confounding and audacious.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: S.N.L. Recap: Teyana Taylor Hosts, the First Trump Awards and More
item.description: A covetous president grabbed up all the trophies on this week’s “Saturday Night Live” broadcast, hosted by Teyana Taylor, star of “One Battle After Another.”
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
